raw_text: Excluding Johnson (2002)? s pattern-matching algorithm, most recent work on finding head? dependencies with statistical parser has used statistical versions of deep grammar formalisms, such as CCG (Clark et al, 2002) or LFG (Riezler et al, 2002)

citing_paper_authors: Ryan, Gabbard | Seth, Kulick | Mitchell P., Marcus
raw_text: Finally, it is not clear that their numbers are in fact comparable to those of Dienes and Dubey on parsed data because the metrics used are not quite equivalent, par tic ularly for (NP*) s: among other differences, unlike Jijkoun and de Rijke? s metric (taken from (Johnson, 2002)), Dienes and Dubey? s is sensitive to the string extent of the antecedent node, penalizing them if the parser makes attachment errors involving the antecedent even if the system recovered the long? distance dependency itself correctly
clean_text: Finally, it is not clear that their numbers are in fact comparable to those of Dienes and Dubey on parsed data because the metrics used are not quite equivalent, particularly for (NP*) s: among other differences, unlike Jijkoun and de Rijke's metric (taken from (Johnson, 2002)), Dienes and Dubey's is sensitive to the string extent of the antecedent node, penalizing them if the parser makes attachment errors involving the antecedent even if the system recovered the long-distance dependency itself correctly.

raw_text: Johnson (2002) used corpus-induced patterns to insert gaps into both gold standard trees and parser output
clean_text: Johnson (2002) used corpus-induced patterns to insert gaps into both gold standard trees and parser output.

raw_text: Correct dependency recovery for object extraction is also difficult for shallow methods such as Johnson (2002) and Dienes and Dubey (2003) .We consider three types of object extraction: object relative clauses, free object relatives, and tough adjectives (Hockenmaier, 2003a)
clean_text: Correct dependency recovery for object extraction is also difficult for shallow methods such as Johnson (2002) and Dienes and Dubey (2003).

clean_text: While Charniak's parser does not generate empty category information, Johnson (2002) has developed an algorithm that extracts patterns from the Treebank which can be used to insert empty categories into the parser's output.

raw_text: Johnson (2002) was the first post-processing approach to non-local dependency recovery, using a simple pattern-matching algorithm on context-free trees
clean_text: Johnson (2002) was the first post-processing approach to non-local dependency recovery, using a simple pattern-matching algorithm on context-free trees.

raw_text: This approach contrasts with Johnson (2002), who treats empty/antecedent identification as a joint task, and with Dienes and Dubey (2003a, b), who always identify empties first and determine antecedents later
clean_text: This approach contrasts with Johnson (2002), who treats empty/antecedent identification as a joint task, and with Dienes and Dubey (2003a, b), who always identify empties first and determine antecedents later.

clean_text: in an abstract sense it mediates the gap-threading information incorporated into GPSG-style (Gazdar et al., 1985) parsers, and in concrete terms it closely matches the information derived from Johnson (2002)'s connected local tree set patterns.

raw_text: In Table 2 we present comparative results, using the PARSEVAL-based evaluation metric introduced by Johnson (2002)? a correct empty category inference requires the string position of the empty category, combined with the left and right boundaries plus syntactic category of the antecedent, if any, for purposes of comparison.9,10 Note that this evaluation metric does not re quire correct attachment of the empty category into 8A complete description of feature templates can be found at http: //nlp.stanford.edu/ ?rog/acl2004/templates/index.html 9For purposes of comparability with Johnson (2002) we used Charniak? s 2000 parser as P. 10Our algorithm was evaluated on a more stringent standard for NP-* than in previous work: control loci-related mappings were done after dislocated nodes were actually relocated by the algorithm, so an incorrect dislocation remapping can render incorrect the indices of a correct NP-* labeled bracketing
clean_text: For purposes of comparability with Johnson (2002) we used Charniak's 2000 parser as P.
